default.description:
This token matches a design property in Figma that does not have a direct CSS equivellent. In this system it will always be a zero value token, and designers should use a line break to create paragraph spacing which better matches how

are written in code.
There is no proper way to define a responsive value for this property so it will remain a zero property value in this system.

unitless-text-properties.description:
The unitless version of these properties are written this way because Figma doesn't support the preferred units, which are added to the description of the token if needed. 

For properties like lineHeight and letterSpacing which Figma only supports in percentage, an equation will be added in the typography composite token to support a smooth representation in Figma, however, they are to be coded in their preferred unit (em, unitless etc).

satoshi.description:
This typeface was chosen as it looks great in darkmode, even at small font sizes. 

It has limited styles which is why not all tailwind fontweights are populated. 

It also has a variable font in it's package for more sophisticated responsive design tokens.

multiplier.description: Change the value of this token to modify every token in the scales.

base.description: Tokens used as the default or "mid-point" in your scale will have this value without any changes. So when you adjust only the multiplier token, this is not affected.

3xs.description: This calculation is modified to avoid a zero value at this very small size.

steps1and2.value: bg for surfaces and subtle components
steps1and2.description:
Steps 1 and 2 are designed for app backgrounds and subtle component backgrounds. You can use them interchangeably, depending on the vibe you're going for.

Appropriate applications include:

-Main app background
-Striped table background
-Code block background
-Card background
-Sidebar background
-Canvas area background
You may want to use white for your app background in light mode, and Step 1 or 2 from a gray or coloured scale in dark mode. In this case, set up a mutable alias for AppBg and map it to a different color for each color mode.

SOURCE - https://www.radix-ui.com/colors/docs/palette-composition/understanding-the-scale

steps3to5.description:
Steps 3, 4, and 5 are designed for UI component backgrounds.

Step 3 is for normal states.
Step 4 is for hover states.
Step 5 is for pressed or selected states.

If your component has a transparent background in its default state, you can use Step 3 for its hover state.

SOURCE - https://www.radix-ui.com/colors/docs/palette-composition/understanding-the-scale

steps6to8.description:
Steps 6, 7, and 8 are designed for borders.

- Step 6 is designed for subtle borders on components which are not interactive. For example sidebars, headers, cards, alerts, and separators.
- Step 7 is designed for subtle borders on interactive components.
- Step 8 is designed for stronger borders on interactive components and focus rings.

SOURCE - https://www.radix-ui.com/colors/docs/palette-composition/understanding-the-scale

steps9and10.description:
Steps 9 and 10 are designed for solid backgrounds.

Step 9 has the highest chroma of all steps in the scale. In other words, it's the purest step, the step mixed with the least amount of white or black. Because 9 is the purest step, it has a wide range of applications:

- Website/App backgrounds
- Website section backgrounds
- Header backgrounds
- Component backgrounds
- Graphics/Logos
- Overlays
- Coloured shadows
- Accent borders

Step 10 is designed for component hover states, where step 9 is the component's normal state background.

Most step 9 colors are designed for white foreground text. Sky, Mint, Lime, Yellow, and Amber are designed for dark foreground text and steps 9 and 10.

steps11and12.description:
Steps 11 and 12 are designed for text.

Step 11 is designed for low-contrast text.
Step 12 is designed for high-contrast text.

Steps 11 and 12—which are designed for text—are guaranteed to Lc 60 and Lc 90 APCA contrast ratio on top of a step 2 background from the same scale.

SOURCE - https://www.radix-ui.com/colors/docs/palette-composition/understanding-the-scale

aliasing.value: read the radix site for more details
aliasing.description:
In a decision token set, you can define alias tokens which reference these primitives. 

The radix docs for engineers does a great job of explaining this approach. 

https://www.radix-ui.com/colors/docs/overview/aliasing

4to5.value: smaller overlay panels like hover card and popover

low.description: classic panel components (like a card) with not much elevation required

high.description: classic panel components (like a card) with higher elevation required

low.description: small panel components that overlay the UI (like a hover card, tooltip, popover) with not much elevation required

high.description: small panel components that overlay the UI (like a hover card, tooltip, popover) with higher elevation required

default.description: large panel components that overlay the UI (like a dialog)

structure.description:
The split button is a modification of component/actions/button as the primary action, and component/actions/toggle-button as the secondary action. 

Limited tokens were needed as overrides for these nested components to modify the styling slightly (border, radius). 

We want the secondary action to expose a menu when selected, which should have the same interaction design as when the toggle-button is selected.

justify-content.description: There currently isn't a token to control this property so the value is pasted from Figma's output of CSS. Please inspect design file.

align-items.description: There currently isn't a token to control this property so the value is pasted from Figma's output of CSS. Please inspect design file.

template.description:
All tokens starting with a design property is known to be a primitive option token which will contain a hard coded value. 

When a token starts with what it is (colors), we know its a primitive option in our token structure.

name-start.description:
The beginning part of the name will be written in camel case. 

The design property will be written in plural. 

Example: fontFamilies

name-group.description:
Any groups needed for primitives will be written in lowercase.

Groups with more than one word in their name will be written with dashes as dots are reserved for additional groups.

There can be more than one group in a primitive token if needed. 

Example: grey, grey-cool, grey-warm

name-end.description:
The end of the token name will be written in lowercase when letters are used. 

We will not use dashes or dots to communicated sub-groups avoid collisions based on flatted names.

Example: 1half represents 1.5 to avoid 15 and 1.5 being flattened into the same name

namespace.description:
Information about the design system, company, usecase, or theme will not be hard coded into tokens names. 

If engineers require them for their workflow, they are to be added during the transformation of tokens.
